standard_metadata.standard_description: Find a percent of a quantity as a rate per 100 (e.g., 30% of a quantity means 30/100 times the quantity); solve problems involving finding the whole, given a part and the percent.

question.content: **What is $1\%$ of $700$?**   *Hint: We can think of $1\%$ as a common fraction.*

hints.content: **Percent** (using the symbol $\%$) means the rate per $100$.  We can write $\blueE{1\%}$ as a fraction to make it faster to multiply the rate by $\maroonD{700}$.

images.alt: Seven hundreds blocks with 1 shaded ones block in each.

question.content: **What is $10\%$ of $390$?**   *Hint: We can think of $10\%$ as a common fraction.*

hints.content: **Percent** (using the symbol $\%$) means the rate per $100$.  We can write $\blueE{10\%}$ as a fraction to make it faster to multiply the rate by $\maroonD{390}$.

$\begin{align} \blueE{10\%} \text{ of }\maroonD{390} &= \blueE{\dfrac{10}{100}} \cdot \maroonD{390}\\\\ &=\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}} \cdot \maroonD{390} \end{align}$  $\blueE{10\%}$ of a number *always* equals $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ of the number.  What is $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ of $\maroonD{390}$?

images.alt: Four hundreds blocks. In each of the first 3 blocks, all 100 squares are shaded, and 10 of those squares are darker. In the last hundreds block, 90 squares are shaded, and 9 of those square are darker. The hundreds blocks are labeled 10, 20, 30, and 39.

question.content: **What is $10\%$ of $20$?**   *Hint: We can think of $10\%$ as a common fraction.*

hints.content: **Percent** (using the symbol $\%$) means the rate per $100$.  We can write $\blueE{10\%}$ as a fraction to make it faster to multiply the rate by $\maroonD{20}$.

$\begin{align} \blueE{10\%} \text{ of }\maroonD{20} &= \blueE{\dfrac{10}{100}} \cdot \maroonD{20}\\\\ &=\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}} \cdot \maroonD{20} \end{align}$  $\blueE{10\%}$ of a number *always* equals $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ of the number.  What is $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ of $\maroonD{20}$?

images.alt: An array of 20 dots arranged in 10 columns of 2 dots each. The rows are labeled from 1 through 2.

images.alt: Five hundreds blocks. In each of the first 4 blocks, all 100 squares are shaded, and 10 of those squares are darker. In the last hundreds block, 70 squares are shaded, and 7 of those square are darker. The hundreds blocks are labeled 10, 20, 30, 40 and 47.

question.content: **What is $10\%$ of $60$?**   *Hint: We can think of $10\%$ as a common fraction.*

hints.content: **Percent** (using the symbol $\%$) means the rate per $100$.  We can write $\blueE{10\%}$ as a fraction to make it faster to multiply the rate by $\maroonD{60}$.

$\begin{align} \blueE{10\%} \text{ of }\maroonD{60} &= \blueE{\dfrac{10}{100}} \cdot \maroonD{60}\\\\ &=\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}} \cdot \maroonD{60} \end{align}$  $\blueE{10\%}$ of a number *always* equals $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ of the number.  What is $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ of $\maroonD{60}$?

images.alt: An array of 60 dots arranged in 10 columns of 6 dots each. The rows are labeled from 1 through 6.

question.content: **What is $20\%$ of $300$?**   *Hint: We can think of $20\%$ as a common fraction.*

hints.content: **Percent** (using the symbol $\%$) means the rate per $100$.  We can write $\blueE{20\%}$ as a simplified fraction to make it faster to multiply the rate by $\maroonD{300}$.

$\begin{align} \blueE{20\%} \text{ of }\maroonD{300} &= \blueE{\dfrac{20}{100}} \cdot \maroonD{300}\\\\ &=\blueE{\dfrac{1}{5}} \cdot \maroonD{300} \end{align}$  $\blueE{20\%}$ of a number *always* equals $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{5}}$ of the number.  What is $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{5}}$ of $\maroonD{300}$?

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal lengths. The first tape is labeled 300. A curved brace over the whole first tape is labeled 100 percent. The second tape is split into 5 equal parts, each labeled 60. A curved brace under the first part of the second tape is labeled 20 percent.

question.content: **What is $25\%$ of $32$?**   *Hint: We can think of $25\%$ as a common fraction.*

hints.content: **Percent** (using the symbol $\%$) means the rate per $100$.  We can write $\blueE{25\%}$ as a simplified fraction to make it faster to multiply the rate by $\maroonD{32}$.

$\begin{align} \blueE{25\%} \text{ of }\maroonD{32} &= \blueE{\dfrac{25}{100}} \cdot \maroonD{32}\\\\ &=\blueE{\dfrac{1}{4}} \cdot \maroonD{32} \end{align}$  $\blueE{25\%}$ of a number *always* equals $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{4}}$ of the number.  What is $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{4}}$ of $\maroonD{32}$?

images.alt: An array of 32 dots arranged in 4 rows of 8 dots each. The columns are labeled from 1 through 8.
